choices.text: It has multiple reducing ends
It can be stored at multiple organs
It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed

questions.text: Glucose is stored in the form of glycogen because? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is compact

 

Glycogen is a multibranched polysaccharide of glucose that serves as a form of energy storage in animals, fungi, and bacteria. It is the main storage form of glucose in the human body as it is compact.

 

In humans, glycogen is made and stored primarily in the cells of the liver and skeletal muscle. Liver glycogen helps to maintain the blood glucose levels in the fasting state. Most of the liver glycogen gets depleted after 18hrs of fasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has multiple reducing ends: Glycogen has multiple non-reducing ends, which facilitate rapid mobilization of glucose, not reducing ends.

 

Option C. It can be stored at multiple organs: Glycogen is mainly stored in the liver and skeletal muscles, not in multiple organs.

 

Option D. It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed: Liver glycogen stores are typically depleted after about 18 hours of fasting, not 1 week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen is stored in a compact form, allowing efficient storage of large amounts of glucose in liver and muscle cells, enabling rapid mobilization of glucose when needed.

questions.text: Alkali disease of livestock is caused by an excess of which of the following minerals? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenium

 

Animals that consume grains containing 5 to 40 mg selenium/kg over a period of several weeks or months suffer from chronic selenosis, known as alkali disease. Signs include liver cirrhosis, lameness, hoof malformations, loss of hair, and emaciation.

 

 It is associated with loss of hair on the mane and tail, hoof deformities, and decreased reproductive performance1. It is caused by toxicity from eating plants or grain with protein-bound, insoluble selenium2. This disease normally occurs in cattle and sheep feeding on seleniferous plants

 

Selenium intoxication can also be acute and subacute (blind staggers type).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manganese:

  • Deficiency: Manganese deficiency can lead to skeletal abnormalities, reproductive issues, and poor growth in livestock.
  • Excess: Excess manganese is rare and typically does not cause a condition similar to alkali disease.

 

Option C. Molybdenum:

  • Deficiency: Molybdenum deficiency can impair the function of molybdoenzymes, leading to metabolic disturbances.
  • Excess: Excess molybdenum can interfere with copper metabolism, leading to copper deficiency (known as molybdenosis) in livestock, characterized by symptoms such as diarrhea, poor growth, and anemia.

 

Option D. Iron:

  • Deficiency: Iron deficiency can lead to anemia, weakness, and poor growth in livestock.
  • Excess: Excess iron can cause toxicity, but it does not cause the specific symptoms of alkali disease. Iron toxicity is more likely to result in gastrointestinal disturbances and liver damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkali disease in livestock is caused by chronic selenium toxicity, leading to liver cirrhosis, hoof malformations, loss of hair, and emaciation. This condition is distinct from the effects of other mineral toxicities or deficiencies.

questions.text: By which mechanism does gene repair occur when mediated by CRISPR-Cas9?(AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-Homologous End joining

 

Common repair mechanism in mammalian cells.

 

  • Error-prone: It can introduce insertions or deletions (indels) at the cut site.
  • This mechanism is frequently used in CRISPR-Cas9 to disrupt gene function (gene knock-out).

 

Many clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)-CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9)-based genome editing technologies take advantage of Cas nucleases to induce DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) at desired locations within a genome. Further processing of the DSBs by the cellular DSB repair machinery is then necessary to introduce desired mutations, sequence insertions, or gene deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision: This repair mechanism corrects single-base lesions that do not significantly distort the DNA helix, typically involving the removal of damaged bases by glycosylases followed by endonuclease action.

 

Option C. Homologous End Joining: This term is not commonly used in the context of DSB repair. The correct term would be Homologous Recombination (HR), which is an accurate repair mechanism but not the predominant one in CRISPR-Cas9-mediated repairs.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair: This mechanism corrects base-pair mismatches and small insertion/deletion loops formed during DNA replication and recombination, but it is not primarily involved in repairing DSBs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 mediated gene repair primarily occurs through Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ), an error-prone repair process that ligates broken DNA ends together, often resulting in small insertions or deletions at the repair site.

questions.text: In urea cycle disorders, which of the following can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylbutyrate

 

In urea cycle disorders ammonia cannot be converted to urea, but alternatively can be converted to glutamine and glycine. Ammonia scavengers phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate react with glutamine and glycine and consequently remove excess of ammonia. Phenylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamate: While glutamate can bind ammonia to form glutamine, it does not directly reduce ammonia levels through excretion.

 

Option C. Isoleucine: An amino acid that does not have a role in reducing ammonia levels in urea cycle disorders.

 

Option D. L-carnitine: Involved in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for beta-oxidation, but it does not play a role in reducing ammonia levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders to reduce ammonia levels by converting ammonia into phenylacetylglutamine, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following has protective as well as lubricating property? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucin

 

Mucins form a protective barrier on epithelial surfaces. They are also found in secretions of the gastrointestinal, respiratory and urogenital tract. They also have lubricating properties.

 

Functions of Mucin:

  1. Membrane-bound mucins participate in various cell-cell interactions.
  2. Protective barrier on epithelial surfaces.
  3. Lubricating properties.
  4. "Mask" certain surface antigens.
  5. Mucins also carry cancer-specific peptide and carbohydrate epitopes.

 

Salient features of Mucin:

  1. Found in secretions of the gastrointestinal, respiratory, and reproductive tracts and also in membranes of various cells.
  2. Exhibit high content of O-glycan chains, usually containing NeuAc.
  3. Contain repeating amino acid sequences rich in serine, threonine, and proline.
  4. Extended structure contributes to their high viscoelasticity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collagen: Collagen provides structural support and strength to tissues but does not have significant lubricating properties.

 

Option C. Albumin: Albumin is a major plasma protein involved in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting various substances but does not have lubricating properties.

 

Option D. Immunoglobulin: Immunoglobulins are antibodies that play a crucial role in immune response but do not provide lubrication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucins have both protective and lubricating properties, forming a barrier on epithelial surfaces and reducing friction in various body tracts. They are essential for maintaining the integrity and function of mucosal surfaces.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity decreases in fasting? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphofructokinase 1

 

Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK-1) is a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis that catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. Its activity is increased in the fed state and decreased during fasting. During fasting, the body's metabolic state shifts to prioritize gluconeogenesis and fatty acid oxidation, leading to a decrease in glycolytic enzyme activities, including PFK-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hormone-sensitive lipase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Mobilizes fatty acids from adipose tissue by breaking down triglycerides.

 

Option B. Glycogen phosphorylase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Breaks down glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in the liver and muscles, providing glucose during fasting.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, a key step in gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: Chimeric DNA is used for? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Organ transplantation

 

Chimeric DNA (also known a recombinant DNA) is used in organ transplantation, especially in bone marrow transplant. It allows for the production of essential therapeutic proteins and other biological products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paternity test:

  • Function: Uses genetic markers to determine biological parentage.
  • Relevance: Typically uses DNA fingerprinting rather than chimeric DNA technology.

 

Option B. Maternity test:

  • Function: Similar to paternity testing, using genetic markers for parentage.
  • Relevance: Uses DNA fingerprinting, not chimeric DNA.

 

Option C. Personal identification:

  • Function: Uses DNA profiling for forensic and legal identification.
  • Relevance: DNA fingerprinting and STR analysis are common methods, not chimeric DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of Chimeric DNA are:

 

  1. Recombinant human insulin
  2. Recombinant human growth hormone (HGH, somatotropin) and other human hormones (e.g. FSH)
  3. Recombinant blood clotting factor VIII and other clotting factors (Factor IX, tPA, hirudin)
  4. Recombinant hepatitis B vaccine, HPV vaccine, etc.
  5. Cytokines and growth factors (interferon, interleukins, etc.)
  6. Monoclonal antibodies and other related products (rituximab, trastuzumab, etc.)
  7. Recombinant enzymes (acid Œ± glucosidase [myozyme], Œ± L iduronidase [aldurazyme])
  8. Recombinant HIV protein for HIV ELISA testing
  9. Herbicide and insect resistant crops
  10. Other products: Bone morphogenic protein (BMP), albumin, fibinolytic and thrombolytic agents, etc.
  11. Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in sit hybridization (FISH).
  12. Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  13. Restriction Fragment Length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SN)
  14. Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  15. Gene therapy and bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: Which of the following types of collagens is involved in wound healing? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type III

 

Collagen III is the first to be synthesized in the early stages of wound healing and is replaced by collagen I, the dominant skin collagen. Initially there is random deposition of collagen during the granulation tissue formation which is further enhanced by enzyme-induced covalent cross-linking. This process matures the collagen into complex structures that are reoriented for tensile strength restoration. Collagen remodeling continues for months after wound closure and the tensile strength of the repaired tissue increases to about 80‚Äì85% of normal tissue if all processes proceed without any perturbations.

 

Note ‚Äì

  • Collagen is a major structural protein found in connective tissue.

 

  • Type I is the most abundant form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type II:

  • Location: Found primarily in cartilage and the vitreous humor of the eye.
  • Function: Provides structural support to cartilage and vitreous body.
  • Disease: Deficiency leads to severe chondrodysplasias and osteoarthritis.

 

Option C. Type IV:

  • Location: Found in basement membranes.
  • Function: Provides structural integrity to the basement membrane.
  • Disease: Deficiency causes Alport syndrome.

 

Option D. Type V:

  • Location: Found as a minor component in tissues containing collagen I.
  • Function: Contributes to the regulation of collagen fibril assembly.
  • Disease: Deficiency causes Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type I (EDS-I).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Properties of Different types of Collagen:

questions.text: Under anaerobic metabolism which of the following substrates yields 3 molecules of ATP? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycogen

 

Breakdown of glycogen yields glucose-6-phosphate which can enter the glycolysis pathway bypassing the first step thus saving one ATP and producing 3 ATPs.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amino acid: Amino acids are not directly involved in anaerobic glycolysis and do not yield ATP through this pathway.

 

Option C. Glucose: The glycolysis of one glucose molecule under anaerobic conditions yields a net gain of 2 ATP molecules, not 3, because the initial phosphorylation step consumes one ATP.

 

Option D. Galactose: Galactose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate, but this conversion involves steps that consume ATP, resulting in a net gain similar to that of glucose, which is 2 ATP molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under anaerobic conditions, glycogen yields 3 molecules of ATP per glucose unit because it enters glycolysis as glucose-6-phosphate, bypassing the initial ATP-consuming step of glycolysis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of glycogen in an excess amount. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Gierke's disease

 

Clinical features are suggestive of Von Gierke‚Äôs disease (type I)

 

Salient features of Von Gierke‚Äôs Disease ‚Äì

 

  • It is the most common type of glycogen storage disease.
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase is deficient.
  • Fasting hypoglycemia that does not respond to stimulation by adrenaline. The glucose cannot be released from liver during overnight fasting .
  • Clinical Features: Hyperlipidemia, lactic acidosis and ketosis.
  • Glucose-6-phosphate is accumulated, so it is channeled to HMP shunt pathway producing more ribose and more purine nucleotides.
  • Purines are then catabolized to uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia
  • Glycogen gets deposited in liver. Massive liver enlargement may lead to cirrhosis.
  • Children usually die in early childhood.
  • Renomegaly

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pompe's disease: This is a glycogen storage disease characterized by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase. It primarily affects muscles and causes cardiomegaly but does not present with the same biochemical profile as Von Gierke‚Äôs disease.

 

Option C. McArdle's disease: This is characterized by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase and primarily affects muscle metabolism, leading to muscle cramps and myoglobinuria after exercise, but not the described biochemical abnormalities or hepatomegaly.

 

Option D. Cori's disease: Also known as Forbes disease or glycogen storage disease type III, it is caused by a deficiency of the debranching enzyme. While it can cause hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, it does not present with the specific profile of ketonemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperlipidemia seen in Von Gierke's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Km of an enzyme = 10 micromole and Kcat = 20 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 2000 nanomole and Kcat = 50 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 4 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes has the highest catalytic efficiency? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec

 

Catalytic efficiency is calculated as Kcat/Km. Higher values of Kcat and lower values of Km gives better catalytic efficiency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Catalytic efficiency, calculated as ùêæùëêùëéùë°/ùêæùëö is maximized with high ùêæùëêùëéùë°‚Äã and low Km‚Äã.

questions.text: Which of the following shows functional assessment of B1 deficiency? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. RBC Transketolase

 

In thiamine deficiency, erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances. Addition of thiamine diphosphate in vitro to erythrocyte lysate resulting in activation of apo transketolase is suggestive of B1 deficiency.

 

Thiamine contains a substituted pyrimidine ring connected to a substituted thiazole ring by means of methylene bridge. The vitamin is then converted to its active co-enzyme form by addition of two phosphate groups, with the help of ATP. It is catalyzed by thiamine pyrophosphotransferase.

 

Physiological Role of Thiamine

 

  1. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: The co-enzyme form is thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). It is used in oxidative decarboxylation of alpha keto acids, e.g. pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the breakdown of pyruvate, to acetyl CoA, and carbon dioxide
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: An analogous biochemical reaction that requires TPP is the oxidative decarboxylation of alpha ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA and CO2
  3. Transketolase: The second group of enzymes that use TPP as co-enzyme are the transketolases, in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway of glucose
  4. The main role of thiamine (TPP) is in carbohydrate metabolism. So, the requirement of thiamine is increased along with higher intake of carbohydrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC Glutathione Reductase:

  • Function: Measures the activity of riboflavin (Vitamin B2).
  • Relevance: Used to assess riboflavin deficiency, not thiamine deficiency.

 

Option C. Serum Thiamine Levels:

  • Function: Direct measurement of thiamine in the blood.
  • Relevance: While it can indicate thiamine levels, it is less specific than functional assays like erythrocyte transketolase activity for assessing functional deficiency.

 

Option D. RBC Glutathione Peroxidase:

  • Function: Measures the activity of selenium and glutathione metabolism.
  • Relevance: Used to assess selenium status, not thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the marked bond in Orange? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrogen bond

 

Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is composed of four deoxyribonucleotides, i.e. deoxyadenylate (A), deoxyguanylate (G), deoxycytidylate (C), and thymidylate (T).

 

These units are linked by 3‚Ä≤ to 5‚Ä≤ phosphodiester bonds (covalent bonds) to form a long polypeptide chain. The nucleotide is formed by a combination of base + sugar + phosphoric acid. The 3‚Ä≤-hydroxyl of one sugar is linked to the 5‚Ä≤-hydroxyl of another sugar through a phosphate group.

 

The DNA strands are held together mainly by hydrogen bonds between the purine and pyrimidine bases. There are two hydrogen bonds between Adenine (A) and Thymine (T) while there are three hydrogen bonds between Cytidine (C) and Guanine (G). The GC bond is therefore stronger than the AT bond.

 

The spatial alignment of the helix allows only purine to pyrimidine base pairing.

 

A-T and C-G base pairs have almost the same shape. A mispairing will disturb the stable double helical structure.

 

 

Other interactions contributing to DNA stability include:

 

  • Hydrophobic effects - DNA has an arrangement wherein the non-polar, uncharged bases are present in the interior of the structure, while the negatively charged phosphates are present on the outside. As the cellular environment is aqueous and polar, the hydrophobic bases in the interior of the helix are kept away from the surrounding water and the hydrophilic heads are exposed and interact with the exterior water. This property increases the solubility of DNA in water.
  • Van der Waals forces - The nitrogenous bases stacked upon one another are spaced based on their van der Waals distance. Van der Waals distance is the distance at which two molecules are attracted to each other. If this distance reduces, the electrons of the two molecules may overlap causing repulsion. These forces are very distance dependent and are inversely proportional to the sixth power of distance (r6). Although a single van der Waals interaction has a very small effect on the overall structure of DNA, the net effect of several interactions leads to substantial stability.
  • Ionic interactions - The electrostatic (ion-ion) repulsion of the negatively charged phosphates on the outside can make DNA potentially very unstable. However, magnesium ions (Mg2+) and cationic proteins along with arginine and lysine residues interact with the negatively charged groups in the DNA and stabilize it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. lonic bond: This type of bond occurs between charged atoms (ions), typically in the form of salts and is not involved in the structure of DNA.


Option B. Covalent bond: Covalent bonds are strong bonds formed by sharing electrons between atoms. In DNA, covalent bonds (phosphodiester bonds) link the sugar-phosphate backbone but are not marked in the provided image.

option D. Phosphodiester Bond: This is a covalent bond that forms the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA. It is not the bond marked in orange in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrogen bonds between purine and pyrimidine bases stabilize the double helix structure of DNA.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

 

The clinical features described are suggestive of McArdle's disease (glycogen storage disease type V), which is caused by a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase. This enzyme deficiency leads to an inability to break down glycogen into glucose in the muscle cells, resulting in exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and accumulation of glycogen in muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle-debranching enzyme:

  • Deficiency: Causes Cori's disease (glycogen storage disease type III).
  • Clinical Features: Highly branched dextrin accumulates in liver and muscle, leading to fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and myopathy.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in the debranching process of glycogenolysis, but the primary symptoms are different from those described in the question.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase 1:

  • Deficiency: Causes Tarui's disease (glycogen storage disease type VII).
  • Clinical Features: Exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and myoglobinuria, similar to McArdle's, but also includes hemolytic anemia due to the enzyme's role in glycolysis in red blood cells.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in glycolysis, not directly in glycogen metabolism.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphatase:

  • Deficiency: Causes Von Gierke's disease (glycogen storage disease type Ia).
  • Clinical Features: Fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis.
  • Note: This enzyme deficiency affects the liver's ability to release glucose, but not directly linked to muscle symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What type of mutation is seen in sickle cell anemia? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Point mutations

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused due to a point mutation in B globin gene wherein adenine is replaced with thymine in the 6th codon of DNA sequence. Thus, the glutamic acid in the 6th position of beta chain of HbA is changed to valine in HbS. This single amino acid substitution leads to polymerization of hemoglobin molecules inside RBCs. This causes a distortion of cell into sickle shape.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insertion: An insertion mutation involves the addition of one or more nucleotide base pairs into the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Option B. Deletion: A deletion mutation involves the removal of one or more nucleotide base pairs from the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Option D. Frameshift mutation: A frameshift mutation is caused by insertions or deletions of a number of nucleotides that are not divisible by three, resulting in a shift in the reading frame of the codons in the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complementation

 

The image shows a blue-white assay which uses the phenomenon of complementation (complementation of the galactosidase gene).

 

Blue-white assay: The target DNA is inserted into a vector. Vector is introduced into host cells for transformation and it grows in the presence of X-gal (X-gal detects active galactosidase). White colonies arise when cells are transformed with recombinant DNA-containing vectors; blue colonies form when cells are transformed with non-recombinant plasmids (i.e., just the vector).

 

Interpretation of Colonies:

 

  • White Colonies: These arise when the lacZ gene is disrupted by the insertion of foreign DNA, preventing the production of active beta-galactosidase. This indicates successful insertion of the foreign DNA.
  • Green Colonies: (Typically represented as blue colonies in traditional descriptions) These form when the lacZ gene remains intact, producing active beta-galactosidase that cleaves X-Gal, resulting in a blue color. This indicates the vector did not take up the foreign DNA or the insert is outside the lacZ gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Translation: This process involves the synthesis of proteins from mRNA and is not related to the phenomenon shown in the image.

 

Option B. Transformation: While transformation is a part of the process where bacterial cells take up the plasmid DNA, the specific phenomenon depicted is complementation in the blue-white screening assay.

 

Option D. Conjugation: This is a method of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria involving direct cell-to-cell contact and is unrelated to the process shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blue-white screening assay uses the complementation of the beta-galactosidase gene to distinguish between bacterial colonies with recombinant and non-recombinant plasmids based on the color change in the presence of X-Gal.

questions.text: Which of the following enhances iron absorption? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Option B: Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) ‚Äì Correct Answer

  • Enhances iron absorption by:
    • Reducing ferric iron (Fe¬≥‚Å∫) to ferrous iron (Fe¬≤‚Å∫) ‚Äî the absorbable form.
    • Forms soluble complexes with iron in the gut, preventing precipitation.
       

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vitamin A: While important for overall health, it does not directly enhance iron absorption.

 

Option C. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Essential for carbohydrate metabolism, but it does not affect iron absorption.

 

Option D. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Important for various metabolic processes but does not directly enhance iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective

 

Vitamin C enhances iron absorption by reducing ferric ions (Fe+++) to ferrous ions (Fe++) and forming a chelate that protects iron from oxidation, thereby facilitating its absorption in the intestine.

choices.text: Benedict test and heat coagulation test
Heat coagulation test and Rothera's test

questions.text: Which test will be positive in starvation state in urine? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rothera‚Äôs test

 

Detectable levels of ketone bodies in urine (ketonuria) are seen in conditions characterized by increased ketogenesis such as starvation. The urine test done for ketone bodies is the Rothera's test in which formation of a purple ring indicates presence of ketone bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benedict test and heat coagulation test: Used to detect reducing sugars (such as glucose, fructose, and lactose) in urine. In the presence of reducing sugars, Benedict's reagent changes color from blue to green, yellow, or red, depending on the concentration of the sugar. This test is not specific to ketone bodies and is used primarily to diagnose conditions like diabetes mellitus where reducing sugars are present in the urine.

 

Option B. Heat coagulation test: Used to detect proteins in urine. When the urine sample is heated, the presence of proteins causes the formation of a precipitate or cloudiness. This test is used to diagnose conditions like proteinuria, seen in kidney disease, but it does not detect ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gerhardt's test - Ketone bodies in urine.
  • Benedict' test - Reducing sugars.
  • Heat coagulation test - Proteins.
  • Rothera‚Äôs test ‚Äì detect Ketone bodies in urine.

choices.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA
Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid

questions.text: Identify the anaplerotic reaction among the following? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate

 

Anaplerotic reactions are ‚Äúfilling up‚Äù reactions or ‚Äúinflux‚Äù reactions or ‚Äúreplenishing‚Äù reactions which supply 4-carbon units to the TCA cycle.

 

The important anaplerotic reactions are:

 

  1. Pyruvate to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase enzyme. It needs ATP.
  2. Glutamate is transaminated to alpha keto glutarate; and aspartate to oxaloacetate.
  3. Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate by NADP+ dependent malic enzyme.

 

The citric acid cycle acts as a source of precursors of biosynthetic pathways, e.g., heme is synthesized from succinyl CoA and aspartate from oxaloacetate. To counterbalance such losses, and to keep the concentrations of the 4-carbon units in the cell, anaplerotic reactions are essential. This is called anaplerotic role of TCA cycle (Greek word, ana = up; plerotikos = to fill)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA: This is not an anaplerotic reaction; it is a part of the link between glycolysis and the TCA cycle.

 

Option C. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetaldehyde: This reaction is part of ethanol fermentation, not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Option D. Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid: This is part of anaerobic glycolysis (fermentation), not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplerotic reactions, such as the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, are crucial for maintaining the levels of TCA cycle intermediates, enabling the cycle to function efficiently and support biosynthetic demands.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best screening investigation for metabolic disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem Mass Spectrometry

  • Two mass spectrometers (MS) are arranged sequentially.
  • The first MS separates big peptides, based on their mass.
  • From this observation, a single peptide can be directed into the second MS (called parent ion or precursor ion). The parent ion enters the collision cell of the second MS. Here the ions collide with argon gas molecules and are broken into smaller ions. These daughter ions (product ions) are detected and quantified by their mass spectrum in the second instrument.
  • The high selectivity of MS-MS is that the parent ion mass and daughter ion mass are used for characterization.
  • The applications of MS-MS include:
    • Identification and quantification of proteins
    • Drug screening
    • Pesticides
    • Pollutants
    • Screening of inborn errors of metabolism, especially organic acidurias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Western blot:

  • Function: Used for detecting specific proteins in a sample using antibody binding.
  • Limitation: Not suitable for broad metabolic disorder screening; used for protein analysis.

 

Option C. PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction):

  • Function: Amplifies DNA sequences for genetic analysis.
  • Limitation: Highly specific for known genetic mutations; not suitable for comprehensive metabolic screening.

 

Option D. Gel electrophoresis:

  • Function: Separates molecules (DNA, RNA, proteins) based on size and charge.
  • Limitation: Not specific or sensitive enough for broad metabolic disorder screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred method for screening metabolic disorders due to its ability to simultaneously analyze multiple metabolites with high sensitivity and specificity.

choices.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
ÔªøÔªøÔªøThe points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group
ÔªøÔªøÔªøThe compound has three ionisable side chains
ÔªøÔªøÔªøThe compound has one ionisable group

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

 

The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B, which corresponds to the pk1, and pk2 of the compound.

 

The above graph resembles the titration curve of the amino acid glycine.

 

Titration curve of Glycine:

 

 

The titration is completed at a pH of 12, where the glycine predominantly exists in the form of H2N - CH2 - COO.

 

pK1, and pK2, correspond to the point where the buffering capacity is maximum.

 

Characteristics of the titration curve:

  • ÔªøÔªøBuffering capacity is referred to as the ability of the amino acid to resist the change in pH due to the addition of acid (H+) or base (OH- equivalents), by accepting or losing the protons respectively.
  • ÔªøÔªøAn ionizable group refers to the group which can either lose or accept a proton and becomes negatively charged or positively charged ion respectively.
  • ÔªøÔªøDuring the titration, the buffering capacity of the compound reaches its maximum, at points where the pKa of the ionizable groups is reached.
  • ÔªøÔªøEach of these pKa are labeled as pK1, pK2, pK3, etc.
  • ÔªøÔªøThe presence of two pKs indicates that the compound has two ionizable groups. Ex. Glycine.
  • ÔªøÔªøThe presence of three or more pKs indicates the presence of side chains on the amino acid, with additional ionizable groups.
  • ÔªøÔªøEx. histidine has three ionizable groups, an amino group, an imidazole group (on the side chain), and a carboxyl group. The pKas of these groups respectively correspond to the pK1, pK2, pK3 of the titration curve of histidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group: Points A and B represent the pKa values, not the range of maximum ionization. The range of maximum ionization would be broader than just the pKa points.

 

Option C. The compound has three ionisable side chains: The graph shows two pKa values, indicating two ionizable groups. A compound with three ionizable groups would have three pKa values.

 

Option D. The compound has one ionisable group: The graph shows two pKa values, indicating two ionizable groups (an amino group and a carboxyl group).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The points A and B on the titration curve represent the maximum buffering capacity of the compound, corresponding to the pKa values of the ionizable groups. The graph shown likely represents an amino acid like glycine, which has two ionizable groups.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose: Accumulation of glucose is associated with disorders like diabetes, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option B. Lactic acid: Accumulation of lactic acid is seen in lactic acidosis and mitochondrial disorders, but not specifically in Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides: While triglycerides are stored fats, their accumulation is not the primary issue in Zellweger syndrome. The critical problem is the accumulation of VLCFA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairments and early childhood death.

questions.text: Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalysed reaction is given by? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A

 

Among the shown options, Gibbs free energy change of an enzyme-catalysed reaction is shown by A.

 

Formation of a product requires the breaking of substrate bonds and conformational change forming a highly unstable transitional state intermediate, it requires energy and this is called Gibbs free energy of activation. In an enzyme-catalysed reaction, this energy barrier is reduced by forming a relatively stable intermediate-enzyme complex. The enzyme provides attachment sites for the substrate and speeds up the rate of reaction. It doesn't change the Gibbs energy of either the substrate or the product. Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalysed reaction (with no intermediate state) is shown in the image given below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: All the reactions have a transition state, but not all reactions have an intermediate state. There are 2 reasons as to why option B

 

  1. ÔªøÔªøÔªøTransition state intermediate usually has higher energy compared to the substrate or product. Very unusually a dip might be seen like this when the enzyme-intermediate complex is more stable than the product, and the product is not formed.
  2. ÔªøÔªøÔªøEvery intermediate state is again, always followed by another transition state. Therefore, every reaction, if it has an intermediate state, needs to have two transition states as shown in the image given below. We don't have 2 such transition states in curve B in the question, which makes it an incorrect answer.

 

 

Option C: Free energy change cannot be a straight line. It has to pass through a high energy intermediate state

 

Option D: Transition energy intermediate never has lower energy compared to the product

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction is best represented by Curve A, which shows the formation of a transition state and the reduction in activation energy, leading to the production of the final product.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder. It occurs due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose:

  • Function: Primary energy source for the brain.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome but is more relevant in conditions like glycogen storage diseases or diabetes.

 

Option B. Lactic acid:

  • Function: Produced during anaerobic metabolism.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is associated with mitochondrial disorders or lactic acidosis, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides:

  • Function: Stored form of energy in adipose tissue.
  • Relevance: Accumulation in the brain is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome; rather, it is associated with lipid storage diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairment and early death in affected children.

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

 

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is a widely used method to amplify specific DNA segments. The process involves three main steps that are repeated in cycles, resulting in the exponential amplification of the target DNA sequence.

 

Steps of PCR:

 

 

The steps of 1, 2 and 3 are repeated results in the exponential amplification of DNA segments of defined length. In each cycle, the DNA strands are doubled. Thus 20 cycles provide for 1 million times amplifications. These cycles are generally repeated by automated instrument, called Thermal cycler.

 

After the amplification procedure, DNA hybridization technique or Southern blot analysis with a suitable probe, shows the presence of the DNA in the sample tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is Denaturation, Annealing, and Extension. These steps are repeated in cycles to exponentially amplify the target DNA segment.

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B)  5‚Äô‚Üí 3‚Äô Exonuclease

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg‚Äôs enzyme) was isolated from Escherichia coli. It is a repair enzyme. It has both 3‚Äô to 5‚Äô and 5‚Äô to 3‚Äô exonuclease activities. When 5‚Äô to 3‚Äô exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

The Klenow fragment retains the polymerization (5' ‚Üí 3' DNA polymerase) and proofreading (3' ‚Üí 5' exonuclease) activities but lacks the 5' ‚Üí 3' exonuclease activity. Because of these retained activities, the Klenow fragment is widely used in recombinant DNA technology for applications that require DNA synthesis and proofreading without the degradation of the DNA template.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3' ‚Üí 5' Exonuclease: The Klenow fragment retains this activity, which allows it to proofread and correct errors during DNA synthesis.

 

Option C. 5' ‚Üí 3' DNA polymerase: The Klenow fragment retains this activity, which is essential for synthesizing new DNA strands.

 

Option D. 3' ‚Üí 5' DNA polymerase: This activity is not applicable in the context of DNA polymerase I and the Klenow fragment, as DNA polymerase functions in the 5' ‚Üí 3' direction for synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I retains the 5' ‚Üí 3' DNA polymerase and 3' ‚Üí 5' exonuclease (proofreading) activities but lacks the 5' ‚Üí 3' exonuclease activity, making it useful for specific applications in recombinant DNA technology.

questions.text: The enzyme that is not used in cholesterol synthesis? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HMG CoA lyase

 

Initially, acetoacetyl CoA is formed by condensation of two molecules of acetyl-CoA by cytosolic thiolase which then enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway along with a molecule of acetyl-CoA.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiolase: Thiolase is involved in the initial steps of cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option B. HMG CoA Reductase: HMG CoA reductase is a key enzyme in the cholesterol synthesis pathway.

 

Option C. HMG CoA Synthase: HMG CoA Synthase: HMG CoA synthase is involved in Both cholesterol synthesis and ketone body synthesis by forming HMG-CoA.

 

Educational Objective :

 

HMG CoA lyase is not used in the cholesterol synthesis pathway; it is involved in ketogenesis.

questions.text: Glucosamines are used in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthritis

 

Glucosamine and chondroitin sulphate are used in the treatment of arthritis which is a degenerative joint disease.

 

Glucosamines are amino sugars. Mucopolysaccharides or glycosamino glycans (GAG) are heteropolysaccharides, containing uronic acid and amino sugars. Acetylated amino groups, sulfate and carboxyl groups are also generally present. Because of the presence of these charged groups, they attract water molecules and so they produce viscous solutions.

 

Examples of mucopolysaccharides are hyaluronic acid, heparin, chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate and keratan sulfate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niemann-Pick disease: This is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by the accumulation of sphingomyelin, not treated with glucosamines.

 

Option C. Alzheimer's disease: This neurodegenerative condition involves the accumulation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Glucosamines are not used in its treatment.

 

Option D. Cancer: Cancer treatment involves a wide range of therapies such as chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. Glucosamines are not used in cancer treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucosamine is used in the treatment of arthritis due to its role in maintaining healthy cartilage and joint function.

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5'-3' Exonuclease

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg‚Äôs enzyme) was isolated from Escherichia coli. It is a repair enzyme. It has both 3‚Ä≤ to 5‚Ä≤ and 5‚Ä≤ to 3‚Ä≤ exonuclease activities. When 5‚Ä≤ to 3‚Ä≤ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

Details of DNA Polymerase I and Klenow Fragment:

  • DNA Polymerase I (Kornberg's enzyme): This enzyme has three activities:
    • 5'->3' polymerase activity (synthesizes DNA)
    • 3'-5' exonuclease activity (proofreading)
    • 5'-3' exonuclease activity (removes RNA primers and repairs DNA)

  • Klenow Fragment: This fragment results from removing the 5'-3' exonuclease domain. It retains:

     

The Klenow fragment is widely used in recombinant DNA technology due to its ability to synthesize DNA and proofread without degrading the DNA template or newly synthesized strand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3'-5' Exonuclease: This proofreading activity is retained by the Klenow fragment.

 

Option C. 5'->3' DNA polymerase: This polymerization activity is also retained by the Klenow fragment.

 

Option D. 3'-5' DNA polymerase: This option is incorrect terminology; which is correctly termed 3'-5' exonuclease and is retained in the Klenow fragment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I lacks the 5'-3' exonuclease activity but retains the 5'->3' polymerase and 3'-5' exonuclease (proofreading) activities, making it useful for DNA synthesis and recombinant DNA technology.

choices.text: Made of amino acids and sugars

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about proteoglycans?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Holds less water

 

Proteoglycans are widely distributed complex molecules having glycosaminoglycans (GAG) and proteins. The GAGs containing repeating disaccharide units are covalently bound to the peptide chain to form proteoglycans. Acetylated amino groups, sulfate and carboxyl groups are also generally present. Because of the presence of these charged groups, they attract water molecules and so they produce viscous solutions.

 

Chondroitin sulfate It is present in ground substance of connective tissues widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea and skin. It is composed of repeating units of glucuronic acid ‚Üí beta-1,3-N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate ‚Üí beta-1, 4 and so on. It is a glycosaminoglycan bound to a protein; hence it is a proteoglycan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carries Negative Charge: Proteoglycans carry negative charges due to the presence of sulfate and carboxyl groups on the GAG chains. These negatively charged groups attract positively charged ions and water molecules.

 

Option B. Chondroitin Sulfate is a Proteoglycan: Chondroitin sulfate is a type of GAG that, when attached to a core protein, forms a proteoglycan. It is widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, and skin.

 

Option C. Made of Amino Acids and Sugars: Proteoglycans are made up of a protein core (composed of amino acids) and one or more GAG chains (composed of sugars).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proteoglycans are complex molecules made of amino acids and sugars, carrying negative charges and holding a significant amount of water due to their hydrophilic nature. Chondroitin sulfate, a type of GAG, forms proteoglycans when bound to a protein.

choices.text: Is coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Interferes with energy production from amino acids

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency results in decreased energy production, because TPP? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Is coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

 

Pyruvate and Œ±-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase use Thiamine as a co-enzyme to produce ATP using NADH.

 

Thiamine also acts as a coenzyme for transketolase in the pentose phosphate pathway (HMP shunt) but there is no ATP generation here, hence option C is correct.

 

Physiological Role of Thiamine:

 

  1. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: The co-enzyme form is thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). It is used in oxidative decarboxylation of alpha keto acids, e.g. pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the breakdown of pyruvate, to acetyl CoA, and carbon dioxide
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: An analogous biochemical reaction that requires TPP is the oxidative decarboxylation of alpha ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA and CO2
  3. Transketolase: The second group of enzymes that use TPP as co-enzyme are the transketolases, in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway of glucose. 
  4. The main role of thiamine (TPP) is in carbohydrate metabolism. So, the requirement of thiamine is increased along with higher intake of carbohydrates

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interferes with alcohol metabolism: While thiamine is important for alcohol metabolism, the primary reason for decreased energy production in thiamine deficiency is its role in the citric acid cycle, not alcohol metabolism.

 

Option B. Interferes with transketolase activity: Although TPP is a coenzyme for transketolase, this enzyme operates in the pentose phosphate pathway, which does not generate ATP.

 

Option D. Interferes with energy production from amino acids: Thiamine's primary role is in carbohydrate metabolism through its function in the citric acid cycle, not directly in amino acid metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiamine deficiency leads to decreased energy production because thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is a critical coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle, essential for ATP generation.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not involved in iron metabolism? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transthyretin

 

Transthyretin is not involved in iron metabolism. It transports thyroxine.

 

Hepcidin, a 25-amino-acid (aa) peptide, is the principal regulator of iron absorption and its distribution to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceruloplasmin: Functions as a ferroxidase, converting Fe2+ (ferrous iron) to Fe3+ (ferric iron), which is essential for iron binding to transferrin for transport.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: A 25-amino-acid peptide that is the principal regulator of iron absorption and its distribution to tissues. It inhibits iron release from enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation.

 

Option D. Transferrin: The main iron transport protein in the blood. It binds and transports iron to various tissues, including the bone marrow for erythropoiesis and the liver for storage.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A TPN bag consists of 100g glucose, 30g amino acids, and 40g lipids. What is the amount of calories delivered? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 880 Kcal

 

In patients who cannot (unconscious; removal of large part of gut) or should not (major trauma or surgery) use their gastrointestinal tract, total parenteral feeding has to be resorted. The solution may be infused through one of the large vessels like subclavian vein or superior vena cava, where the blood flow is sufficient to dilute the hypertonic solution. This procedure is known as total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or intravenous hyperalimentation.

 

The number of calories delivered by the given TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) bag is 880 Kcal.

 

The caloric values of different food components are:

‚Ä¢ Carbohydrate (glucose) - 4KCal/g

‚Ä¢ Proteins (amino acids) - 4.2KCal/g = ~4KCal/g

‚Ä¢ Fat (lipids) - 9Kcal/g

 

Calculation of the number of calories:

‚Ä¢ 100 gm of glucose = 100 √ó 4 KCal=400 KCal

‚Ä¢ 30 gm of amino acids = 30 √ó 4 KCal= 120 KCal

‚Ä¢ 40 gm of lipids = 40 √ó 9 KCal= 360 KCal

Total amount of calories delivered= 400+120+360=880 Kcal

 

Note: The caloric value of alcohol is 7KCal/g.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is a method used to deliver nutrients directly into the bloodstream when patients cannot use their gastrointestinal tract. The caloric value of the nutrients provided in the TPN bag can be calculated based on the caloric content of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.

 

Caloric Values:

 

  • Carbohydrates (glucose): 4 KCal/g
  • Proteins (amino acids): Approximately 4 KCal/g
  • Fats (lipids): 9 KCal/g

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason for using phenylbutyrate in urea cycle disorders? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It scavenges nitrogen

 

In urea cycle disorders ammonia cannot be converted to urea, but alternatively can be converted to glutamine and glycine. Ammonia scavengers phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate react with glutamine and glycine and consequently remove excess of ammonia. Phenylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in urine.

 

Phenylbutyrate is metabolized into phenylacetate, which conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine. Similarly, sodium benzoate conjugates with glycine to form hippurate. Both phenylacetylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in the urine, thereby reducing the levels of ammonia in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It maintains renal output: While phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate are excreted in the urine, their primary function is not to maintain renal output but to remove excess ammonia.

 

Option C. It maintains energy production: Phenylbutyrate does not directly impact energy production. Its primary role is to help remove excess ammonia from the body.

 

Option D. It activates enzymes: Phenylbutyrate does not activate enzymes. Instead, it works by conjugating with amino acids to facilitate the removal of ammonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders to scavenge nitrogen by reacting with glutamine, converting excess ammonia into phenylacetylglutamine, which is then excreted in the urine.

choices.text: Human cells can divide a finite number of times only
Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted
RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only

questions.text: What is true about the Hayflick limit? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human cells can divide a finite number of times only

 

Leonard Hayflick discovered that cultured normal human cells have limited capacity to divide, after which they become senescent ‚Äî a phenomenon now known as the ‚ÄòHayflick limit‚Äô.

 

Each time a cell undergoes mitosis, the telomeres on the ends of each chromosome shorten slightly. Cell division will cease once telomeres shorten to a critical length. Hayflick interpreted his discovery to be aging at the cellular level. The aging of cell populations appears to correlate with the overall physical aging of an organism. Normal human fetal cell population will divide between 40 and 60 times in cell culture before entering a senescence phase. However, this limit does not apply to stem cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted: Free radical oxidation is related to oxidative stress and damage but is not directly related to the Hayflick limit.

 

Option C. Telomerase activity is unrestricted: In most somatic cells, telomerase activity is limited, leading to telomere shortening. However, certain cells like stem cells and cancer cells exhibit higher telomerase activity, allowing them to bypass the Hayflick limit.

 

Option D. RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only: RNA polymerase activity is not directly linked to the Hayflick limit and does not have a finite number of times it can function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hayflick limit describes the finite number of times that normal human cells can divide before they become senescent, primarily due to telomere shortening.

questions.text: Ammonia in the brain is detoxified to form? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamine

 

First Line of Defense (Trapping of Ammonia) - Being highly toxic, ammonia should be eliminated or detoxified, as and when it is formed. Even very minute quantity of ammonia may produce toxicity in central nervous system. But, ammonia is always produced by almost all cells, including neurons. The intracellular ammonia is immediately trapped by glutamic acid to form glutamine, especially in brain cells. The glutamine is then transported to liver, where the reaction is reversed by the enzyme glutaminase. The ammonia thus generated is immediately detoxified into urea. Aspartic acid may also undergo similar reaction to form asparagine.

 

 

Ammonia trapping as glutamine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urea: Urea is the primary form of nitrogen excretion in the liver, but it is not the form in which ammonia is detoxified in the brain.

 

Option C. Ammonium ions: Ammonium ions can be a form of ammonia detoxification in the kidney, but not the primary method in the brain.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine plays a role in transporting ammonia from muscle to the liver, but it is not the primary detoxification product in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the brain, ammonia is detoxified by converting it to glutamine, which is then transported to the liver for further detoxification into urea.

questions.text: DNA Methylation is not involved in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Base pair excision

 

Base pair excision repair (BER) is a mechanism that corrects DNA damage involving small, non-helix-distorting base lesions. This process is initiated by DNA glycosylases that recognize and remove damaged bases, followed by endonuclease activity, DNA synthesis, and ligation. DNA methylation does not play a direct role in this repair pathway.

 

DNA methylation is usually associated with triggering histone deacetylation, chromatin condensation, and gene silencing. Differentially methylated cytosines give rise to distinct patterns specific for each tissue type and disease state. Such methylation-variable positions (MVPs) are not uniformly distributed throughout our genome, but are concentrated among genes that regulate transcription, growth, metabolism, differentiation, and oncogenesis. Alterations in MVP methylation status create epigenetic patterns that appear to regulate gene expression profiles during cell differentiation, growth, and development, as well as in cancer.

 

Environmental stressors including toxins, as well as microbial and viral exposures, can change epigenetic patterns and thereby effect changes in gene activation and cell phenotype.

It is involved in mismatch repair but not in the base pair excision repair mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Roles of DNA Methylation:

 

Option A. Chromatin Remodeling: DNA methylation is involved in chromatin remodeling by recruiting proteins such as methyl-CpG-binding domain proteins (MBDs) that interact with histone deacetylases (HDACs), leading to chromatin condensation and gene silencing.

 

Option B. Mismatch Repair: DNA methylation marks newly synthesized DNA strands during replication, aiding in the identification and repair of mismatches.

 

Option C. Gene Silencing: DNA methylation typically leads to gene silencing by preventing the binding of transcription factors and promoting the formation of a condensed chromatin structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA methylation is not involved in the base pair excision repair mechanism. Instead, it plays significant roles in chromatin remodeling, mismatch repair, and gene silencing by modifying the DNA structure and influencing protein interactions and gene expression.

choices.text: tRNA of Alanine
U6 SnRNA
mRNA for Histone

questions.text: Which of the following does not require 5' capping? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) tRNA of Alanine

 

5’ capping - Eukaryotic mRNAs are all ‘capped’ at the 5′ terminus by 7-methyl guanosine triphosphate. An unusual 5’ to 5′ triphosphate bridge is seen. This happens inside the nucleus. The cap is useful in recognition of mRNA by the translating machinery and in prevention of degradation by exonucleases.

 

Poly-A Tailing at 3′ End - The 3’ terminus is polyadenylated in the nucleoplasm. This

poly-A tail may be 20 to 250 nucleotides long. This tail protects mRNA from attack by 3′ exonuclease.

 

Note: tRNA do not require capping at 5’ end.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. U6 SnRNA:

  • Function: U6 snRNA is part of the spliceosome complex involved in RNA splicing.
  • Modification: U6 snRNA is not typically capped with 7-methyl guanosine but may undergo other modifications.

 

Option C. mRNA for Histone:

  • Function: Histone mRNAs are unique in that they typically do not have poly-A tails but do require 5' capping.
  • Modification: Despite lacking poly-A tails, histone mRNAs still undergo 5' capping.

 

Option D. SiRNA (Small interfering RNA):

  • Function: SiRNAs are involved in the RNA interference pathway, leading to the degradation of target mRNAs.
  • Modification: SiRNAs are typically not capped at the 5' end as they are processed from longer double-stranded RNA precursors.

 

Educational objective:

 

tRNA, including tRNA for alanine, does not require 5' capping. This modification is specific to mRNAs and some snRNAs, playing a critical role in mRNA stability and translation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement regarding telomerase? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Involved in DNA repair

 

Telomerase is not primarily involved in DNA repair. While telomere maintenance can influence genome stability and prevent end-to-end chromosome fusions, telomerase itself does not play a direct role in the classical DNA repair pathways such as base excision repair, nucleotide excision repair, mismatch repair, or double-strand break repair.

 

Telomerase is a specialized enzyme that adds repetitive nucleotide sequences to the ends of chromosomes (telomeres) in eukaryotic cells. Its primary function is to maintain the length and stability of chromosomes by compensating for the loss of DNA that occurs during cell division.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Telomeres are repetitive non-coding DNA sequences at the ends of chromosomes that protect them from degradation and prevent chromosomal fusion.
  • Telomerase activity declines with age, leading to the progressive shortening of telomeres and eventual cell senescence or apoptosis.
  • In many cancer cells, telomerase activity is upregulated, allowing these cells to bypass senescence and continue dividing indefinitely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Has reverse transcriptase activity: Telomerase contains an RNA component that serves as a template for adding telomeric repeats to the chromosome ends. The enzyme uses this RNA template to synthesize DNA, acting as a reverse transcriptase.

 

Option B. Present only in Eukaryotes: Telomerase is found only in eukaryotic cells because prokaryotic chromosomes are typically circular and do not have telomeres that require maintenance.

 

Option C. Maintains the chromosome length: Telomerase extends the telomeres, preventing their shortening during DNA replication and thus maintaining chromosome length and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telomerase is an enzyme with reverse transcriptase activity, present only in eukaryotes, and is crucial for maintaining chromosome length by adding telomeric repeats. It is not directly involved in DNA repair.

choices.text: It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA
It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins

questions.text: True regarding Mitochondrial DNA is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA

 

Mitochondrial DNA and RNA

 

  1. There is a dichotomy on the mitochondrial metabolism. Some of the mitochondrial protein synthesis is under the control of mitochondrial DNA; but important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA.
  2. The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular, has about 16,500 nucleotides. The mtDNA has information for synthesis of 2 ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 proteins. All of them are components of electron transport chain. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (total of 67 i.e., about 20%). However, most of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.
  3. Maternal inheritance: Since, the mitochondria are inherited cytoplasmically, the mtDNA is inherited from the mother. Mother transmits mtDNA through oocyte.
  4. There are hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell (nuclear DNA has only 2 copies).
  5. Heteroplasmy is defined as the presence of normal and mutant mtDNA in different proportions in different cells. During cell division, mtDNA replicates and they segregate to the daughter cells. If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA.
  6. High mutation rate: 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA
  7. Age-related accumulation of mutations in mtDNA may be responsible for age-related decrease in cellular OXPHOS function, and progression of other degenerative diseases.
  8. Defects in mitochondrial genome will lead to mitochondrial myopathies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One set from each parent: Incorrect. mtDNA is inherited only from the mother.

 

Option C. It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins: Incorrect. mtDNA encodes about 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain, approximately 20% of the total, not more than 25%.

 

Option D. It has 3 X 10^9 base pairs: Incorrect. mtDNA is much smaller, with about 16,500 base pairs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA, is maternally inherited, and contains 37 genes encoding essential components of the electron transport chain.

 

Ref - Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students 7th edition

questions.text: The given chemical structure is of: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chondroitin sulphate

 

Chondroitin sulphate is present in ground substance of connective tissues widely distributed in cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea and skin. It is composed of repeating units of glucuronic acid → beta-1,3-N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate → beta-1, 4 and so on.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Keratan Sulphate:

  • Composition: Contains galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine.
  • Location: Found in cartilage, cornea, and intervertebral discs.

 

Option C. Heparin:

  • Composition: Contains glucuronic acid or iduronic acid and glucosamine.
  • Location: Primarily found in mast cells and used as an anticoagulant.

 

Option D. Dermatan Sulphate:

  • Composition: Contains iduronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine.
  • Location: Found in skin, blood vessels, and heart valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chondroitin sulphate is a glycosaminoglycan found in connective tissues like cartilage and bone, characterized by its repeating units of glucuronic acid and N-acetyl galactosamine sulphate.

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. Musty odor is present in the baby's sweat and urine. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

 

The given clinical history is suggesting a most probable diagnosis of phenylketonuria (PKU)

Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase is the cause for this disease.

 

Biochemical Abnormalities:

  1. Phenylalanine cannot be converted to tyrosine. So, phenylalanine accumulates. Phenylalanine level in blood is elevated.
  2. So alternate minor pathways are opened. Phenylketone (phenylpyruvate), phenyllactate and phenylacetate are excreted in urine.

 

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  1. The classical PKU child is mentally retarded with an IQ of 50.
  2. Agitation, hyperactivity, tremors and convulsions are often manifested. This may be because phenylalanine interferes with neurotransmitter synthesis.
  3. The child often has hypopigmentation, explained by the inhibition of tyrosinase.
  4. Phenyl acetic acid in sweat may lead to mousy body odor.

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  1. Blood phenylalanine: Normal level is 1 mg/dL. In PKU, the level is >20 mg/dL. This may be demonstrated by chromatography. Tandem mass spectroscopy is the most reliable test; but is costly.
  2. Guthrie test is a rapid screening test - Certain strains of Bacillus subtilis need phenylalanine as an essential growth factor. Bacteria cannot grow in a medium devoid of phenylalanine. Bacterial growth is proportional to the phenylalanine content in the patient‚Äôs blood.
  3. Ferric chloride test: Urine of the patient contains phenylketones about 500‚Äì3000 mg/day. This could be detected by adding a drop of ferric chloride to the urine. A transient blue-green color is a positive test. But this is a less reliable test.
  4. DNA probes are now available to diagnose the defects in phenylalanine hydroxylase and dihydrobiopterin reductase.

 

Treatment:

  1. Early detection is very important. About 5 units of IQ are lost for each 10-week delay in starting the treatment.
  2. The treatment is to provide a diet containing low phenylalanine (10‚Äì20 mg/kg body weight per day)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme defect: True: This is the primary defect in PKU, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels.

 

Option C. Phenylacetate positive in urine: True: Phenylacetate, a metabolite of phenylalanine, is found in the urine of patients with PKU.

 

Option D. Mental retardation is present: True: Without early treatment, children with PKU often suffer from severe mental retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PKU is characterized by a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels and its metabolites, which cause neurological symptoms, hypopigmentation, and a musty odor. Early detection and dietary management are crucial for preventing severe mental retardation.

choices.text: It does not depend on the macronutrients

questions.text: Which of the following is Thermogenic food? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High protein diet

 

Increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food is called as thermogenic effect of food or diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action (SDA) of food (non-shivering thermogenesis).

 

Part of this is due to the expenditure of energy for digestion; absorption and active transport of products of the digestion. Another reason for this expenditure of energy is that reserve materials, such as glycogen, triacyl glycerol, protein, etc. are synthesized from small molecules available after digestion.

 

A high protein diet leads to higher protein turnover resulting in increased diet induced thermogenesis.

 

The values of SDA are: for proteins 30%, for lipids 15%, and for carbohydrates 5%. This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.

Thermogenesis results from the presence of an uncoupling protein, thermogenin, in the inner mitochondrial membrane.

 

It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High fat diet: While fats do contribute to thermogenesis, their specific dynamic action (SDA) is lower (15%) compared to proteins (30%).

 

Option B. It does not depend on the macronutrients: This statement is incorrect, as the thermogenic effect of food does depend on the type of macronutrient consumed.

 

Option D. High carbohydrate diet: Carbohydrates have a lower thermogenic effect (5%) compared to proteins (30%).

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high protein diet has the highest thermogenic effect compared to fats and carbohydrates, leading to increased energy expenditure during digestion and metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following TCA cycle intermediate is a part of heme metabolism? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Succinyl CoA

 

TCA cycle is truly amphibolic (both catabolic and anabolic) in nature. Since various compounds enter into or leave from TCA cycle, it is sometimes called as ‚Äúmetabolic traffic circle‚Äù.

 

  • Succinyl CoA and Heme Synthesis:
    • Function: Succinyl CoA combines with glycine to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA), which is the first step in the synthesis of heme.
    • Enzyme Involved: The enzyme ALA synthase catalyzes this reaction in the mitochondria.
    • Importance: Heme is a vital component of hemoglobin, myoglobin, and various cytochromes involved in electron transport and drug metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha Ketoglutarate:

  • Function: Precursor for the synthesis of glutamate and subsequently other amino acids.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Option B. Fumarate:

  • Function: Intermediate in the TCA cycle, involved in the conversion of fumarate to malate.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Option D. Malate:

  • Function: Intermediate in the TCA cycle, involved in the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important anabolic reactions related with citric acid cycle are:

  1. Oxaloacetate is the precursor of aspartate
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate can be made into glutamate
  3. Succinyl CoA is used for synthesis of heme
  4. Mitochondrial citrate is transported to cytoplasm, where it is cleaved into acetyl CoA, which then is the starting point of fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following does not favor euchromatin formation due to changes occurring at Cytosine residues at Cp islands in DNA?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methylation 

 

Euchromatin is a form of chromatin that is loosely packed and transcriptionally active, allowing for the expression of genes. The formation and maintenance of euchromatin are influenced by various post-translational modifications of DNA and histones.

 

Methylation of Cytosine Residues at CpG Islands:

 

  • CpG Islands: These are regions of DNA with a high frequency of CpG dinucleotides, often found near gene promoters and regulatory regions.
  • Methylation: The addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues in CpG islands is associated with gene silencing and the formation of heterochromatin (inactive, condensed chromatin). This methylation process hinders the binding of transcription factors and other regulatory proteins, leading to a more compact chromatin structure and reduced gene expression.
  • Impact on Euchromatin: Methylation of cytosine residues is a key epigenetic modification that does not favor euchromatin formation because it inactivates the DNA, leading to a transcriptionally inactive state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphorylation: Phosphorylation of histones can promote chromatin remodeling and gene expression, thus favoring euchromatin formation.

 

Option C. Alkylation: Alkylation typically refers to the addition of alkyl groups to DNA or histones, which can have varying effects. However, it does not specifically inhibit euchromatin formation in the way that methylation does.

 

Option D. Sumoylation: Sumoylation involves the addition of small ubiquitin-like modifier (SUMO) proteins to histones or other proteins. This modification generally influences protein stability and function, but it does not directly interfere with euchromatin formation like methylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methylation of cytosine residues at CpG islands is associated with gene silencing and the formation of transcriptionally inactive heterochromatin, thus not favoring euchromatin formation.

choices.text: Glutamine replaced by asparagine
Glutamine replaced by alanine
Glutamine replaced by glutamate
Glutamine replaced by arginine

questions.text: Which of the following would have no effect on the function of the protein product? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glutamine replaced by asparagine

 

Amino acid replacement is a change from one amino acid to a different amino acid in a protein due to point mutation in the corresponding DNA sequence. It is caused by nonsynonymous missense mutation which changes the codon sequence to code other amino acid instead of the original.

 

Usually, amino acids are thus classified into two types:

 

  1. Conservative replacement - an amino acid is exchanged into another that has similar properties. This type of replacement is expected to rarely result in dysfunction in the corresponding protein.

For example, leucine and isoleucine are both aliphatic, branched hydrophobes. Similarly, aspartic acid and glutamic acid are both small, negatively charged residues.

 

  1. Radical replacement - an amino acid is exchanged into another with different properties. This can lead to changes in protein structure or function, which can cause potentially lead to changes in phenotype, sometimes pathogenic.

 

Example - Sickle cell anemia, due to a mutation in beta globin where at position 6 glutamic acid (negatively charged) is exchanged with valine (not charged).

 

Other Options:
