Option B. Glutamine replaced by alanine: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while alanine is a nonpolar, aliphatic amino acid. This radical replacement could affect the protein's structure or function.

 

Option C. Glutamine replaced by glutamate: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while glutamate is a polar, negatively charged amino acid. Although they are similar in size, the difference in charge makes this a radical replacement, potentially affecting protein function.

 

Option D. Glutamine replaced by arginine: Glutamine is a polar, uncharged amino acid, while arginine is a polar, positively charged amino acid. This radical replacement could significantly alter the protein's structure or function.

 

Educational Objective

 

Conservative replacements, such as replacing glutamine with asparagine, typically do not affect the protein's function because the substituted amino acids have similar properties. Radical replacements, involving amino acids with different properties, are more likely to impact protein function.

questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off and tingling sensation of limbs and at times weakness of limbs. She had a history of eating paint from the wall of a newly built house. Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ALA dehydratase

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of lead poisoning and lead is known to inhibit ALA dehydratase enzyme activity (zinc-containing enzyme).

 

Lead is the most common environmental poison in India. Paint is the major source for exposure, especially in children.

 

More than 10 mg/dL in children and more than 25 mg/dL in adults leads to toxic manifestations.

Anemia, abdominal colic and loss of appetite are very common symptoms.

 

Lead inhibits heme synthesis. Basophilic stippling of red cells is seen in the peripheral blood and bone marrow smears. This is due to the agglutination of ribosomes. Globin synthesis is adversely affected. Lead particularly inhibits ALA-dehydratase and ferrochelatase. Lifespan of RBC is shortened. Anemia enhances lead absorption, lead in turn produces more anemia; thus, a vicious cycle is operating. Lead will inhibit absorption of iron and calcium.

 

Treatment - Calcium dodecyl edetate (Calcium disodium versenate), penicillamine and dimercaprol (BAL) are used as antidotes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ALA synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the first step in heme synthesis but is not directly inhibited by lead.

 

Option C. Heme synthase: Also known as ferrochelatase, this enzyme inserts iron into protoporphyrin IX to form heme. Although lead inhibits this enzyme, ALA dehydratase is more significantly affected in lead poisoning, causing the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Coproporphyrinogen oxidase: This enzyme catalyzes a later step in heme synthesis and is not primarily affected in lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead poisoning inhibits ALA dehydratase, causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, tingling, and weakness of limbs. Paint ingestion, particularly in children, is a significant source of lead exposure.

questions.text: In a reaction, the substrate is available in a concentration that is 1000 times the Km value of the enzyme. After 9 minutes of reaction, 1% of substrate is converted to product (12 microgram/ml). If the concentration of the enzyme is changed to 1/3 and concentration of substrate is doubled, what is the time taken to convert the substrate into the same amount of product that i.e., 12 microgram/ml? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 27 minutes

 

The time taken for the formation of the same amount of product is 27 minutes.

 

When the substrate concentration is much greater than the Km value, the rate of the reaction is independent of the substrate concentration i.e., it follows zero-order kinetics. In this reaction, the substrate concentration is 1000 times the Km value therefore it follows zero-order kinetics. So, doubling the substrate concentration does not change the velocity of the reaction.

 

The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the enzyme. As the enzyme concentration becomes 1/3rd, the velocity of the reaction also becomes 1/3rd.

 

Therefore, the time taken for the formation of the same amount of product will become tripled. That is, 9 √ó 3 = 27 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In zero-order kinetics, the reaction rate is independent of substrate concentration but directly proportional to enzyme concentration. Reducing the enzyme concentration to 1/3 increases the time taken to produce the same amount of product by a factor of 3.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with features as shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tryptophan

 

The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4). It is seen in patients with pellagra, as a result of niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency or tryptophan deficiency.

 

Deficiency of niacin leads to the clinical condition called pellagra. Pellagra is an Italian word, meaning ‚Äúrough skin‚Äù. Pellagra is caused by the deficiency of Tryptophan as well as Niacin. Pellagra is seen more in women; this may be because tryptophan metabolism is inhibited by estrogen metabolites.

 

The symptoms of pellagra are (3 Ds):

 

  1. Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs, especially in the feet, ankles and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal necklace. The dermatitis is precipitated by exposure to sunlight
  2. Diarrhea: The diarrhea may be mild or severe with blood and mucus. This may lead to weight loss. Nausea and vomiting may also be present.
  3. Dementia: It is frequently seen in chronic cases.

 

Delirium is common in acute Pellagra. Irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory are more common in mild cases. Ataxia, and spasticity are also seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option.  A. Phenylalanine, C. Glutamine: and D. Arginine: Deficiency of these amino acids are not associated with pellagra.

 

Educational Objective

 

Pellagra can occur due to:

 

  • ÔªøÔªøVitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency
  • ÔªøÔªøTryptophan deficiency: Niacin is synthetised from tryptophan
  • Deficient synthesis: Kynureninase, an important enzyme in the pathway of tryptophan, is pyridoxal phosphate dependent. So, conversion of tryptophan to niacin is not possible in pyridoxal deficiency.
  • Isoniazid (INH): It is an anti-tubercular drug, which inhibits pyridoxal phosphate formation. Hence, there is block in conversion of tryptophan to NAD.
  • Hartnup disease: Tryptophan absorption from intestine is defective in this congenital disease. Moreover, tryptophan is excreted in urine in large quantities. This leads to lack of tryptophan and consequently deficiency of nicotinamide.
  • Carcinoid syndrome: The tumor utilizes major portion of available tryptophan for synthesis of serotonin; so, tryptophan is unavailable.

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyruvate Carboxylase

 

Raw eggs contain a protein called avidin, which binds to biotin and prevents its absorption in the intestine. Biotin is a vital coenzyme for several carboxylase enzymes, including pyruvate carboxylase. When biotin is deficient, these enzymes cannot function properly, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, particularly during moderate exercise.

 

Mechanism:

  • Avidin in Raw Eggs: Binds strongly to biotin, preventing its absorption and leading to biotin deficiency.
  • Pyruvate Carboxylase Deficiency: Results in impaired gluconeogenesis and energy production, causing fatigue during exercise.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 Phosphate:

  • Function: Involved in glycogenolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • Relevance: Not related to biotin deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Option C. PEPCK (Phosphoenolpyruvate Carboxykinase):

  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate in gluconeogenesis.
  • Relevance: Although involved in gluconeogenesis, its activity is not directly dependent on biotin.

 

Option D. Glycogen Phosphorylase:

  • Function: Breaks down glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in glycogenolysis.
  • Relevance: Not related to biotin deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eating raw eggs can lead to biotin deficiency due to avidin binding, resulting in a deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase. This enzyme deficiency impairs gluconeogenesis, causing fatigue during exercise. Supplementing biotin can correct the deficiency and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following can alter the gene expression by methylation and acetylation but not change the gene sequence? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epigenetics

 

Epigenetics refers to the study of changes in gene function that are heritable through cell division (mitotic and meiotic) but do not involve alterations in the DNA sequence. Epigenetic modifications can regulate gene expression by altering the accessibility of transcription factors to the DNA.

 

Mechanisms of Epigenetics:

 

  1. Histone Acetylation: The acetylation of specific lysine residues in core histones (H3 and H4) leads to an open chromatin structure, facilitating the access of transcription factors to the DNA and thereby promoting gene transcription.
  2. DNA Methylation: The addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues, particularly at CpG dinucleotides within gene promoters, leads to chromatin condensation and transcriptional repression.

Epigenetic modifications such as methylation and acetylation play crucial roles in regulating gene expression and can influence various biological processes, including development, differentiation, and carcinogenesis, without altering the underlying DNA sequence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation: Mutations involve changes in the DNA sequence, such as substitutions, deletions, or insertions, which can affect gene function and expression.

 

Option C. Translocation: This refers to the rearrangement of parts between nonhomologous chromosomes, which involves changes in the DNA sequence and can disrupt gene function.

 

Option D. Inversion: An inversion is a chromosomal rearrangement in which a segment of a chromosome is reversed end to end, involving changes in the DNA sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epigenetics involves modifications such as methylation and acetylation that regulate gene expression without changing the DNA sequence, playing a crucial role in various biological processes and diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act when RFLP is used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GATATC- CTATAG

 

Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) is a difference in homologous DNA sequences that can be detected by the presence of fragments of different lengths after digestion of the DNA samples in question with specific restriction endonucleases.

 

Restriction endonucleases have specific recognition sites where they cut the DNA. These enzymes recognize specific sequence with palindrome arrangement. These are also called inverted repeat sequences, which means the nucleotide sequence in 5‚Ä≤ to 3‚Ä≤ direction is the same in both strands.

 

Option B. is a palindromic sequence, hence the correct the answer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: ATGGAC ‚Äì TACGTG 

 

  • This is not a palindrome.
  • 5'-ATGGAC
    3'-TACCTG 

 

Option C: TAGATA ‚Äì ATCTAT 

 

  • Not a palindrome.
  • 5'-TAGATA
    3'-ATCTAT

 

Option D: AATATA ‚Äì TATAAT 

 

  • 5'-AATATA
    3'-TATAAT
  • Not a palindrome either. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In RFLP, restriction enzymes recognize and cut at palindromic sequences in DNA. The palindromic sequence GATATC-CTATAG is a correct recognition site for these enzymes, making it crucial for identifying different species, such as staphylococci in a surgical ICU.

questions.text: The attachment of Eukaryotic mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Guanyl cap

 

In eukaryotic cells, the attachment of mRNA to the ribosome is facilitated by the presence of a 5' cap structure, specifically an N7-methylguanosine (m7G) cap, also known as the guanyl cap. This cap is essential for several functions, including the initiation of translation.

 

Functions of the Guanyl Cap:

 

  1. Initiation of Translation: The 5' cap is recognized by the eukaryotic initiation factors (eIFs), particularly eIF4E, which is a part of the eIF4F complex. This recognition is crucial for the recruitment of the ribosome to the mRNA.
  2. Protection: The cap structure protects the mRNA from degradation by 5' to 3' exonucleases.
  3. Splicing and Export: The cap structure also plays roles in pre-mRNA splicing, polyadenylation, and the export of mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Poly A tail: The polyadenylation (poly A tail) at the 3' end of mRNA enhances stability and facilitates the export of mRNA from the nucleus. It also aids in the regulation of translation but does not directly mediate ribosome attachment.

 

Option B. tRNA: Transfer RNA (tRNA) is involved in the translation process by bringing amino acids to the ribosome during protein synthesis, but it does not mediate the attachment of mRNA to the ribosome.

 

Option D. Shine-Dalgarno Sequence: The Shine-Dalgarno sequence is a ribosomal binding site found in prokaryotic mRNA. It helps in the alignment of the ribosome with the start codon, but it is not present in eukaryotic mRNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The attachment of eukaryotic mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through the 5' guanyl cap, which plays a crucial role in the initiation of translation, protection of mRNA, and its processing and export from the nucleus.

questions.text: Which modification will lead to Various short and long-acting analogs of the hormone given in the picture ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Change in 29-30 in B chain 

 

Explanation:

 

The hormone depicted in the image is insulin.  

 

Insulin's primary structure consists of two polypeptide chains: the A chain (21 amino acids) and the B chain (30 amino acids).  

 

There are two interchain disulfide bonds: 

  • Between the 7th amino acid of the A chain and the 7th amino acid of the B chain. 
  • Between the 20th amino acid of the A chain and the 19th amino acid of the B chain. One intrachain disulfide bond exists between the 6th and 11th amino acids of the A chain. 

Modifications in amino acids 29-30 of the B chain result in the production of short- and long-acting insulin types, depending on the changes made 

 

Other Options Explanation: 

 

Option A. Hydrolysis of disulphide bonds: Disrupts the structural integrity of insulin, leading to loss of biological activity. 

 

Option B. Change in 5-6 in A chain: Changing the sequence in the critical A chain can affect the folding and activity of insulin. 

 

Option D. Change in 14-16 in A chain: Changing the sequence in the A chain can disrupt the structure and function of insulin. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissured tongue and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B2

 

Natural deficiency of riboflavin in man is uncommon, because riboflavin is synthesized by the intestinal flora. Riboflavin deficiency usually accompanies other deficiency diseases such as beriberi, pellagra and Kwashiorkor. Nutritional status of riboflavin can be determined by measuring the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

 

Manifestations: Symptoms are confined to skin and mucous membranes.

 

  1. Glossitis (Greek, glossa = tongue)
  2. Magenta colored tongue
  3. Cheilosis (Greek, cheilos = lip)
  4. Angular stomatitis (inflammation at the corners of mouth)
  5. Circumcorneal vascularization
  6. Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries is the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency.
  7. Personality changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Deficiency causes beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, but is detected by erythrocyte transketolase activation assay.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): Deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy and is detected by activation of erythrocyte transaminases.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin): Deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms, detected by serum methyl malonate and homocysteine levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency, indicated by reduced glutathione reductase activity, can cause symptoms such as a fissured tongue, cheilosis, and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: The best method to measure HbA1c is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ion exchange chromatography

 

Glycated hemoglobin (GHB), reported as hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), is a biochemical marker that is used routinely in the management of individuals with diabetes mellitus to monitor long-term glycemic control and assess the risk of developing complications.

 

The fraction of hemoglobin glycated, normally about 5%, is proportionate to blood

glucose concentration. Since the half-life of an erythrocyte is typically 60 days, the level of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) reflects the mean blood glucose concentration over the preceding 6‚Äì8 weeks.

 

Four basic types of methods are used most commonly to measure HbA1c: immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays.

 

Ion-exchange HPLC separates Hb species based on charge differences between HbA1c and other hemoglobins. It is considered as a gold standard for HbA1c analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoelectric focusing:

  • Function: Separates proteins based on their isoelectric points.
  • Limitation: Not commonly used for HbA1c measurement due to complexity and lower specificity for glycated hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Affinity chromatography:

  • Function: Uses specific binding interactions to separate molecules.
  • Limitation: While effective in some contexts, it is not the most common method for routine HbA1c measurement.

 

Option D. Electrophoresis:

  • Function: Separates proteins based on their size and charge under an electric field.
  • Limitation: Not as specific or reliable for HbA1c measurement compared to ion-exchange HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ion-exchange chromatography is considered the gold standard for measuring HbA1c due to its high accuracy and ability to separate HbA1c from other hemoglobin variants based on charge differences.

choices.text: Glycogenesis in muscle
Increased protein synthesis
Increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA
Decreased cholesterol synthesis

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl suffers from an inadequately treated type 1 diabetes mellitus. She is currently hyperglycemic. Which of the following is most likely to occur? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA

 

Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). In cases like Type 1 diabetes mellitus where insulin is deficient, uninhibited activity of HSL in adipocytes leads to breakdown of lipid into fatty acids (lipolysis) which will further undergo beta-oxidation and produce a large amount of acetyl CoA. This then gets converted to ketone bodies (acetoacetate, acetone, beta-hydroxybutyrate, etc.)

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Glycogenesis in Muscle: Glycogenesis (formation of glycogen from glucose) is stimulated by insulin. In the absence of insulin, glycogenesis is decreased, not increased.

 

Option B. Increased Protein Synthesis: Insulin promotes protein synthesis. In its absence, as in type 1 diabetes mellitus, protein synthesis is decreased, and protein catabolism is increased.

 

Option D. Decreased Cholesterol Synthesis: While insulin does influence cholesterol synthesis, the primary metabolic changes in type 1 diabetes mellitus are related to glucose and lipid metabolism. The increased lipolysis and subsequent ketogenesis are more pronounced effects.

 

Educational Objective

 

In type 1 diabetes mellitus with inadequate insulin, the most likely occurrence is the increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA due to uninhibited hormone-sensitive lipase activity, leading to increased lipolysis and subsequent ketogenesis.

questions.text: The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skin- Liver- Kidney

 

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is skin-liver-kidney.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The synthesis of vitamin D follows the sequence of Skin ‚Üí Liver ‚Üí Kidney, with each organ playing a critical role in converting the precursor to its active form.

questions.text: DNA methylation is not related to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Capping

 

DNA methylation is usually associated with triggering histone deacetylation, chromatin condensation, and gene silencing. Differentially methylated cytosines give rise to distinct patterns specific for each tissue type and disease state. Such methylation-variable positions (MVPs) are not uniformly distributed throughout our genome, but are concentrated among genes that regulate transcription, growth, metabolism, differentiation, and oncogenesis.

 

Alterations in MVP methylation status create epigenetic patterns that appear to regulate gene expression profiles during cell differentiation, growth, and development, as well as in cancer.

 

Environmental stressors including toxins, as well as microbial and viral exposures, can change epigenetic patterns and thereby effect changes in gene activation and cell phenotype.

 

Note - Capping is done for mRNA (7-methyl guanosine cap) not DNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mismatch repair: DNA methylation is involved in distinguishing parental DNA strands during the mismatch repair process.

 

Option B. Chromatin Remodeling: DNA methylation plays a significant role in the remodeling of chromatin structure.

 

Option D. Gene silencing: DNA methylation is a key mechanism involved in the silencing of genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA methylation is not related to RNA capping, which is an mRNA modification process. Instead, it is involved in processes such as mismatch repair, chromatin remodeling, and gene silencing.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is based on RNA? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RT-PCR

 

RT PCR is RNA-based technique.

 

It is the method used to amplify, isolate or identify a known sequence from a cell or tissue RNA library. Essentially normal PCR is preceded by reverse transcription (to convert the RNA to cDNA). This is widely used in expression mapping, determining when and where certain genes are expressed. Tth polymerase from Thermus thermophilus may be used. This enzyme has both DNA polymerase and reverse transcriptase activities at high temperature. This allows both cDNA synthesis from mRNA followed by PCR amplification.

In ordinary PCR, DNA is detected; that DNA could be from a living or non-living organism. But in reverse PCR, mRNA is detected; that means, it is derived from a living organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sanger's technique - Sanger sequencing, also known as the ‚Äúchain termination method‚Äù, is a method for determining the nucleotide sequence of DNA.

 

Option C. Next-generation DNA sequencing technologies also called deep sequencing, is a technology that enables parallel multiplexed analysis of DNA sequences on a massive scale.

 

Option D. Western blot is used to detect specific protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is an RNA-based technique that involves reverse transcription of RNA into cDNA followed by PCR amplification, widely used in gene expression analysis.

questions.text: Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibition

 

Vitamin K Dependent Carboxylase is microsomal enzyme. It requires oxygen, CO2, NADPH and reduced vitamin K. In this process, the vitamin passes through a cycle. This process is competitively inhibited by warfarin and dicoumarol.

 

 

Vitamin K cycle

 

Dicoumarol - Structural analog inhibits vitamin K reductase

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicide inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds irreversibly to the enzyme, inactivating it permanently.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol does not irreversibly inactivate vitamin K reductase.

 

Option C. Noncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, not the active site, altering the enzyme's activity.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol competes at the active site, not at a different site.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing the reaction from proceeding.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol binds to the enzyme regardless of the presence of the substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by competitively inhibiting vitamin K reductase, preventing the regeneration of active vitamin K necessary for blood clotting.

questions.text: Which of the following does not happen in 5' to 3' direction?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RNA editing

 

  • RNA editing is not a synthesis process; it involves modification of the pre-existing RNA sequence after transcription.
  • It may include: Base substitution (e.g., A-to-I, C-to-U)
  • Directionality (5‚Ä≤ to 3‚Ä≤) does not apply to these post-transcriptional modifications in the same way it applies to polymerization.
  • An example of RNA editing is apoB gene and mRNA
     

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transcription: Occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, where RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA from a DNA template.

 

Option B. DNA Replication: Occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, with DNA polymerase adding nucleotides to the growing DNA strand.

 

Option C. DNA Repair: DNA repair processes, including nucleotide excision repair and base excision repair, involve synthesis in the 5' to 3' direction during the filling in of repaired regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RNA editing, such as the editing of the apolipoprotein B mRNA, can involve modifications that do not occur in the 5' to 3' direction, unlike transcription, DNA replication, and DNA repair.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not formed after post-translational modification? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenocysteine

 

Selenocysteine is abbreviated as SeCys is the 21st human amino acid.

It is formed by co-translational modification.

 

It is seen at the active site of the following enzymes:

 

  1. Thioredoxin reductase
  2. Glutathione peroxidase, which scavenges peroxides;
  3. De-iodinase that removes iodine from thyroxine to make triiodothyronine
  4. Selenoprotein P, a glycoprotein seen in mammalian blood.

 

Replacement of Secys by Cys will lead to decreased activity of these enzymes.

Deficiency of these enzymes may be related with atherosclerosis, as these enzymes have an antioxidant function. Their concentration falls in selenium deficiency.

 

Its structure is COOH‚ÄìCHNH2‚ÄìCH2‚ÄìSeH. It is incorporated into protein during translation process. There is a tRNA, specific to carry Secys. The codon is UGA. Biosynthesis of selenocysteine is by replacing the oxygen of serine by selenium; this is done by two steps:

 

  1. Se + ATP ‚Üí Se-P + AMP + Pi
  2. Serine + Se-P ‚Üí SeCys + Pi

 

The code for SeCys is UGA, which is identified by a SeCys insertion element in the mRNA, with the help of a specific elongation factor. The tRNA-Sec is first charged with serine, then it is converted into SeCys. This is then inserted into the correct position, when protein is synthesized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triiodothyronine (T3): Formed by post-translational modification of thyroxine (T4) through the enzymatic removal of an iodine atom.

 

Option C. Hydroxyproline: Formed by post-translational hydroxylation of proline, a process critical for the stability of collagen.

 

Option D. Hydroxylysine: Formed by post-translational hydroxylation of lysine, also important in collagen stability.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The enzyme that is common for both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphoglycerate kinase

 

Phosphoglycerate kinase catalyzes the conversion of 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate to 3-phosphoglycerate, which is a reversible step involved in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis hence it is common for both pathways.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyruvate kinase: Pyruvate kinase is involved only in glycolysis and catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate. It is not involved in gluconeogenesis.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis, converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. It does not play a role in gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase: Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase is involved in gluconeogenesis, converting oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate. It is not involved in glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphoglycerate kinase is a common enzyme in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, catalyzing a reversible reaction that interconverts 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate and 3-phosphoglycerate.

 

Other reversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:

  • Phosphoglycerate mutase
  • Glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Triose phosphate isomerase
  • Aldolase
  • Phosphohexose isomerase

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease will act on which of the following? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) AAGCTT

 

Restriction endonucleases have specific recognition sites where they cut the DNA. These enzymes recognize specific sequence with palindrome arrangement. These are also called inverted repeat sequences, which means the nucleotide sequence in 5‚Äô to 3‚Äô direction is the same in both strands.

 

AAGCTT is a palindromic sequence and other 3 options are not palindromic sequence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: AAGAAG
‚Ä¢    Complement: 3‚Ä≤-TTCTTC5‚Äô 
‚Ä¢    Not palindromic
‚Ä¢    Not recognized by any common restriction enzyme

 

Option B: GAGAGG
‚Ä¢    Complement: 3‚Ä≤-CTCTCC 5‚Äô
‚Ä¢    Not a palindrome
‚Ä¢    Not a restriction site

 

Option D: TACGAG
‚Ä¢    Complement: 3‚Ä≤-ATGCTC 5‚Äô
‚Ä¢    Not a palindrome
‚Ä¢    Not recognized by known restriction enzymes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Restriction endonucleases act and cleave at the site of a palindromic sequence, such as:

 

5' --AAGCTT-- 3'

3' --TTCGAA-- 5'

questions.text: The catalytic efficiency of enzyme is best expressed by which of the following kinetic constants? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kcat/Km

 

The catalytic efficiency is the ratio of Kcat/Km.

 

Kcat is the first-order rate constant that determines the reaction rate when the enzyme is fully occupied at a saturating concentration of the substrate.

 

The Michaelis constant (Km), defined as the concentration of substrate that is transported at half the maximal velocity (Vmax) of transport, is a measure of the affinity of the transporter for its substrate.

 

Decreasing the catalytic efficiency or the quantity of the catalyst for the "bottleneck" or rate-limiting reaction therefore reduces metabolite flux through the entire pathway. Conversely, an increase in either its quantity or catalytic efficiency enhances flux through the pathway as a whole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is best expressed by the ratio Kcat/Km, as it provides a measure of how effectively the enzyme converts substrate into product, considering both the enzyme's turnover rate and its substrate affinity.

questions.text: Which among the following serves as cofactor for Glycogen phosphorylase? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyridoxal Phosphate

 

Glycogen phosphorylase removes glucose as glucose- 1-phosphate from glycogen (phosphorolysis). It contains pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a prosthetic group. The alpha-1, 4 linkages in the glycogen are cleaved.

 

PLP also acts as the coenzyme for many enzymes involved in

 

  • Amino acid metabolism, especially transamination and decarboxylation
  • Heme synthesis
  • Production of niacin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine is a cofactor for enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism, such as pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, but it is not a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option B. Niacin: Niacin is a precursor for NAD and NADP, which are important cofactors in redox reactions, but it does not serve as a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. Biotin: Biotin is a cofactor for carboxylation reactions, such as those catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase, acetyl-CoA carboxylase, and propionyl-CoA carboxylase, but it is not involved with glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is the cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase and is also involved in amino acid metabolism, heme synthesis, and niacin production.

choices.text: Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount

questions.text: The maximum thermic effect is seen with a meal which has? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Protein

 

Increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food is called as thermogenic effect of food or diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action (SDA) of food.

 

Part of this is due to the expenditure of energy for digestion; absorption and active transport of products of the digestion. Another reason for this expenditure of energy is that reserve materials, such as glycogen, triacyl glycerol, protein, etc. are synthesized from small molecules available after digestion.

 

A high protein diet leads to higher protein turnover resulting in increased diet induced thermogenesis.

 

The values of SDA are: for proteins 30%, for lipids 15%, and for carbohydrates 5%. This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.

It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fat: Fats have a moderate thermic effect, lower than proteins.

 

Option C. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have the lowest thermic effect.

 

Option D. Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount: A mixed meal would have a combined thermic effect that is a weighted average of the individual macronutrient effects, which would be lower than that of a protein-only meal.

 

Real-world Observation: It is commonly observed that after consuming a protein-rich meal, especially during hot weather, individuals may feel hot and humid due to the increased heat production. Conversely, in cold weather, the same meal can provide a warming effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum thermic effect is seen with protein-rich meals, as proteins require more energy for digestion, absorption, and metabolism compared to fats and carbohydrates.

questions.text: In SCID, what type of DNA repair is defective? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-homologous end joining repair

 

Human severe combined immune deficiency (SCID) is the most serious inherited immunological deficit which is caused due to defects in the predominant pathway for double-strand break repair called nonhomologous DNA end joining, or NHEJ.

 

Defects in DNA Repair:

 

 

Other Options: 

 

The table in the provided image highlights various DNA repair pathways and the associated cancer syndromes when these pathways are defective:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Base modifications, abasic sites
  • Cancer Syndromes: Not yet reported

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Intra-strand crosslinks, bulky adducts
  • Cancer Syndromes: Xeroderma pigmentosum, ERCC6L2 deficiency

 

Option C. Mismatch repair (MMR):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Mismatches, indels
  • Cancer Syndromes: Constitutional MMR syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCID is caused by defects in the NHEJ pathway, which is responsible for repairing double-strand breaks in DNA. This defect impairs the immune system, leading to severe immunodeficiency.

 

Non-homologous end joining (NHEJ):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Double-strand breaks (DSBs)
  • Cancer Syndromes: Ligase IV deficiency, XLF/NHEJ1 deficiency, Rothmund-Thompson syndrome, Werner syndrome

questions.text: Vitamin K in its coenzyme form is regenerated by the enzyme? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epoxide reductase

 

Vitamin K plays a crucial role in the carboxylation of glutamic acid residues in proteins to form gamma-carboxyglutamate, which is important for blood clotting. The active form of vitamin K is required for this carboxylation reaction. After participating in the carboxylation reaction, vitamin K is converted to its epoxide form. To be reused, this epoxide form must be converted back to its active hydroquinone form.

 

The enzyme epoxide reductase is responsible for this conversion. It reduces vitamin K epoxide back to the active hydroquinone form, thus regenerating the coenzyme form of vitamin K. This process is essential for the continuous availability of active vitamin K for carboxylation reactions.

 

 

Fig: Vitamin K cycle.

 

Dicoumarol - a structural analog inhibits vitamin K reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutathione reductase: This enzyme is involved in the reduction of glutathione disulfide to glutathione, and is not involved in the regeneration of vitamin K.

 

Option B. Quinone reductase: This enzyme reduces quinones to hydroquinones but is not specifically responsible for the regeneration of vitamin K's active form.

 

Option C. Vitamin K reductase: While it plays a role in the vitamin K cycle, the specific enzyme responsible for regenerating the coenzyme form of vitamin K from its epoxide form is epoxide reductase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epoxide reductase regenerates the active coenzyme form of vitamin K from its epoxide form, ensuring the continuous availability of active vitamin K for critical carboxylation reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in low insulin-glucagon ratio?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glycogen storage

 

A low insulin: glucagon ratio (IGR) stimulates mobilization of stored nutrients, increases glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, ketogenesis and promotes the breakdown of adipose tissue into free fatty acids and glycerol.

 

Conversely, glycogen storage is not promoted during a low insulin-glucagon ratio. Glycogen storage occurs in a high insulin state, where insulin promotes the uptake and storage of glucose as glycogen in liver and muscle tissues.

 

Other Options :

 

The processes influenced by a low IGR include:

 

Option A. Glycogen Breakdown (Glycogenolysis): The breakdown of glycogen into glucose is stimulated to provide immediate energy.

 

Option B. Ketogenesis: The production of ketone bodies from fatty acids occurs in the liver as an alternative energy source, particularly for the brain during prolonged fasting.

 

Option D. Gluconeogenesis: The synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors such as lactate, glycerol, and amino acids is enhanced to maintain blood glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective :

 

A low insulin-glucagon ratio stimulates the mobilization of energy stores by promoting glycogen breakdown, ketogenesis, and gluconeogenesis, while it inhibits glycogen storage.

questions.text: Fluoroacetate is a component of pesticides. Which of the following metabolic pathways is inhibited by this compound? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TCA cycle

 

Sodium fluoroacetate, is usually used as a rodenticide. It is highly toxic towards humans and other mammals through inhibition of the enzyme aconitase in the tricarboxylic acid cycle (metabolic uncoupler), caused by 'lethal synthesis' of an isomer of fluorocitrate (FC). FA is found in a range of plant species and their ingestion can cause the death of ruminant animals.

 

Inhibition of the TCA Cycle by Fluoroacetate:

  • Aconitase: Converts citrate to aconitate.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate is metabolized to fluorocitrate, which inhibits aconitase, leading to the accumulation of citrate and disruption of the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycolytic pathway:

  • Function: Converts glucose to pyruvate, generating ATP.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not affect glycolysis.

 

Option C. Oxidative phosphorylation:

  • Function: Produces ATP through the electron transport chain and ATP synthase.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option D. ETC (Electron Transport Chain):

  • Function: Transfers electrons from NADH and FADH2 to oxygen, generating ATP.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not directly inhibit the electron transport chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitors of TCA Cycle

questions.text: What would be the respiratory quotient if someone is on an exclusive carbohydrate diet? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

The respiratory quotient (RQ) is defined as the ratio of the volume of CO2 produced to the volume of O2 consumed during metabolism. The RQ value varies depending on the type of substrate being metabolized.

 

Respiratory Quotient Values of Carbohydrates:

 

The RQ for carbohydrates is 1. This is because the metabolism of carbohydrates involves the complete oxidation of glucose, which produces CO2 and consumes O2 in a 1:1 ratio. The equation for glucose oxidation is:

 

When an individual is on an exclusive carbohydrate diet, the metabolism of carbohydrates is the primary source of energy, leading to an RQ value of 1. In conditions like diabetes mellitus, where the utilization of carbohydrates is impaired and fat metabolism predominates, the RQ falls below 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory quotient (RQ) is defined as the ratio of volume of CO2 produced in L/g to the oxygen consumed in L/g.

questions.text: The illustration below shows alternative splicing of a gene which has intron segments 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It yields two products A and B, by the action of different promoters. You are provided with the promoters W, X, Y, and Z, each of which binds to a different segment as shown below and acts in the marked direction. Which of the following promoters will you use to get product A? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. W Y

 

Explanation:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene. In the case of this question, product A is formed by including specific

segments and excluding others through the process of alternative splicing.

 

  • Sequence A consists of segments 1, 3, 4, and 5.
    • Promoter W Required for segment 1.
    • Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5.
    • Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.

 

Thus, the combination of Promoters W and Y will result in the production of sequence A by including

the correct segments and excluding segment 2.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a (W, X, Y): This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it

    is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A.

  • Option b (W, Z): Promoter Z does not include segments 3, making this option incorrect for generating product A.
  • Option c (WX): Promoters W and X are insufficient because they do not include segments 3, 4, and 5, which are essential for product A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene.

 

Using promoters W, Y will yield product A by including segments 1, 3, 4, and 5 and removing segment 2 through alternative splicing.

questions.text: Vitamin C cannot be produced in humans due to lack of? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L-gulonolactone oxidase

 

Most animals and plants can synthesize ascorbic acid from glucose. Man, higher primates, guineapigs and bats are the only species which cannot synthesize ascorbic acid (block in gulonolactone oxidase step). They lack the genes responsible for the synthesis of this enzyme.

 

Details of L-gulonolactone Oxidase:

  • Role: This enzyme is responsible for converting L-gulonolactone to ascorbic acid (vitamin C).
  • Deficiency: Humans, higher primates, guinea pigs, and certain other species lack this enzyme due to mutations or absence of the gene encoding it, which blocks the synthesis of ascorbic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Xylitol reductase: This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of xylitol to xylulose but is not related to the synthesis of vitamin C.

 

Option C. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: This enzyme complex plays a critical role in converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in cellular respiration but is not involved in vitamin C synthesis.

 

Option D. UDP glucose dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of UDP-glucuronic acid from UDP-glucose but has no role in vitamin C production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Humans cannot synthesize vitamin C due to the lack of the enzyme L-gulonolactone oxidase, which is necessary for the final step in the biosynthetic pathway of ascorbic acid from glucose.
